Campylobacters are thin, curved, Granl-negative motile rod bacteria. In GI am smears, S-shaped, seagullshaptd and sometimes long spiral form. may be seen. Many of the animd pathogens are commensals of thLoral cavity, geniral tract and intesr inal tract. Some non-patho-genic species are saprophytes in the environment.

Cjejuni is the main species of concern in dogs and cats, in which it causes enteritis. The role of Ccoli as a cause of disease in animals is unclear although it is excreted by pets and is zoonotic. C jejuni is microaerophilic (requires oxygen for growth) and, although it does not grow outside the body, it may survive in water for long periods, resisting chilling and freezing.

The organisms are spread by the faecal-oral route with the main sources of infection for pet animals being undercookedlraw food (liver, chicken, tripe and unpasteurised milk), water and direct (fresh diarrhoea from infected animals) or indirect (contaminated feeding/ water bowls, other implements) contact with infected animals. Infection is most common in groups of animals in kennels and animal homes but can occur in individuals.

Accurate figures for the incidence of campylobacteriosis in pet animals in the UK are difficult to obtain. According to different studies, Campylobacter species may be isolated from benveen 20 and 30 per cent of diarrhoeic pet dogs and In colonies, however, up to IOO per cent of dogs may be asymptomatic excretors of Campylobacter. Thus, it is evident that a carrier state exists and, in addition, Campylobacter species may be found in diarrhoea as an opportunist infection (eg, secondary to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, malabsorption, giardiasis, coronavirus and parvovirus infections). A positive isolation of C jejuni is, therefore, not necessarily diagnostic for campylobacteriosis.
Infections occur in many domestic mammals (including dogs and cats) and birds (including chickens, parrots and other pet birds) although infection of rabbits and other children's pets is uncommon.

Isolation of the organisms from fresh (less than 24-hour-old) faeces and rectal swabs/scrapes are the most reliable methods for diagnosis. If cultures ofsamples are to be delayed, they should be stored in Cary Blair medium at 4°C. All Campylobacter isolates from animals should be treated as potentially zoonotic and should therefore be fully identified.

Campylobacter and salmonella infections are the most common causes of enteritis in humans and are the commonest zoonoses. In humans, campylobacters cause an acute but self-limiting enteritis which lasts approximately 10 days. Symptoms include fever, headache, abdominal pain, vomiting and diarrhoea (often blood stained). More rarely, signs of arthritis, septicaemia and abortion are observed. Most infections are mild and mortality is extremely unusual. Diagnosis depends on identification of the organism from fresh faecal samples and it is usual to carry out serotyping.

The duration of the severe diarrhoea associated with Campylobacter infection can be reduced by antimicrobial treatment. Although most infections are self-limiting, with animals making a complete recovery without treatment, treatment is recommended ro minimise the risk to Further reeding
